mods:mods.abstract: Internalizing disorders are a broad category of psychopathology in children characterized by children's reactions to stress that occur within the self, such as emotional distress related to feelings of anxiety and depression. Perfectionism, which is defined as high standards of performance which are accompanied by tendencies for overly critical evaluation of one's own behavior, is a well-defined risk factor for internalizing psychopathology in children and across the lifespan. Despite this risk, there is currently a lack of efficacious treatment options targeting perfectionism in children. Therefore, more research is needed to both a) understand maintaining mechanisms of perfectionism in children, and b) continue the development and investigation of treatments targeting those factors. Chapter 2 describes the development and evaluation of a measure of a novel construct hypothesized to be relevant to the development of perfectionism in children, parent sensitivity to children's errors, described as the extent to which parents are distressed by their children's mistakes. Exploratory factor analysis revealed a stable 3-factor structure consisting of Checking Behaviors, Evaluative Worry, and Emotional Investment. Total and individual factor scores demonstrated good internal reliability and associations with relevant constructs. Mediation models demonstrated that parent sensitivity to child errors predicted overprotective parenting behaviors, which in turn predicted child anxiety symptoms. These data demonstrate that parent sensitivity to child errors may be one important factor that can contribute to parenting behaviors that increase risk for perfectionism and associated psychopathology in children. In Chapter 3, I developed and evaluated the efficacy of a novel intervention targeting perfectionism in children. This intervention consisted of a single, virtual study visit in which both parents and children were encouraged to decrease certain behaviors related to perfectionism in children. There were no group differences on primary outcomes of perfectionism or related internalizing symptoms. However, post-hoc analyses suggested that parents and children in the control group decreased perfectionism-related behaviors, and that these behavior reductions predicted decreases in perfectionism and internalizing symptoms regardless of group assignment. Overall, these data suggest that parents and children are able to decrease perfectionism-related behaviors following a single study visit, and that reductions in these behaviors can be an effective approach for treating perfectionism and related internalizing symptoms.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Norman B. Schmidt, Professor Directing Dissertation; Martin Alan Swanbrow-Becker, University Representative; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Jesse R. Cougle, Committee Member; Chris W. Schatschneider, Committee Member.
